Selecting only episodic memory would be too narrow and miss the shared system the neurologist is referencing.
option_explanations.C: Procedural memory is a form of nondeclarative memory dependent on the basal ganglia and cerebellum, not the hippocampus. The vignette directly demonstrates intact procedural memory through bicycle riding, making this option incompatible with the described deficits.
option_explanations.D: Declarative memory — encompassing both episodic (personally experienced events) and semantic (factual world knowledge) subtypes — critically depends on hippocampal consolidation for long-term storage and retrieval. The patient's inability to consciously recall both a recent personal event and a well-known fact, while retaining implicit memory functions, precisely identifies the hippocampally-dependent declarative memory system the neurologist is describing.

questions.source_summary: Episodic and semantic memory are types of declarative memory.
questions.vignette: A 55-year-old man who recently suffered a brain injury can still tie his shoes, ride a bicycle, and shows a measurable advantage on a word identification task when briefly shown a list of words the prior day — even though he has no awareness of having seen the list. His wife reports that he cannot remember their wedding anniversary last month or tell her the name of the sitting president, and he becomes frustrated because he is clearly making a deliberate effort to bring the information to mind. A consulting specialist notes that the two types of information the man cannot access share a common characteristic: both required him at some point to deliberately encode and store them with the intention of later being able to consciously recall them.
questions.question: The consultant's observation about the two types of lost information best characterizes a deficit in which memory system?

options.A: Implicit memory
options.C: Declarative memory
options.D: Nondeclarative memory

option_explanations.A: Implicit memory encompasses memory processes that operate outside of conscious awareness, such as priming, procedural learning, and conditioned responses. The vignette demonstrates intact implicit memory through the patient's bicycle riding and the word identification advantage — but the deficits involve intentional, conscious recall, which is the opposite of implicit memory's defining feature.
option_explanations.B: Episodic memory is one subtype of declarative memory and accounts for the man's inability to recall his wedding anniversary, a personally experienced event. However, his inability to name the sitting president reflects a failure of semantic memory — general factual knowledge — which is a separate subtype. The consultant's observation encompasses both deficits under one system, making the broader category of declarative memory the more precise and complete answer.
option_explanations.C: Declarative memory is the overarching system for consciously accessible, explicitly encoded information, comprising both episodic memory (personal events) and semantic memory (factual world knowledge). The man's failure to recall both a personal anniversary and a public fact, combined with his deliberate effort to retrieve them and the consultant's statement that both share a common characteristic of intentional encoding and conscious retrieval, together uniquely identify a deficit in the declarative memory system.
option_explanations.D: Nondeclarative memory refers to memory systems that operate without conscious awareness or deliberate retrieval, including procedural skills and priming. The vignette explicitly shows these systems are intact — the man rides a bicycle and benefits from prior word exposure without awareness — making nondeclarative memory the preserved system, not the impaired one.

questions.source_summary: Retroactive interference occurs when more recently acquired information interferes with the ability to recall previously acquired information.
questions.vignette: A psychology student spends the weekend studying French vocabulary for an upcoming exam. The following week, she begins an intensive course in Spanish and learns hundreds of new vocabulary words. When she sits down to review for her French exam, she finds that the new information from Spanish class is disrupting her ability to recall the previously learned French words she had studied earlier. Her professor explains that this is a classic memory phenomenon in which more recently acquired material impairs retrieval of earlier material.
questions.question: Which memory phenomenon BEST explains the student's difficulty recalling French vocabulary after studying Spanish?

options.A: Proactive interference
options.C: Encoding specificity
options.D: Decay theory

option_explanations.A: Proactive interference occurs when older, previously learned information disrupts the recall of newer information — the reverse of what is described here. In this scenario, it is the new Spanish learning that is impairing recall of the old French material, not the other way around.
option_explanations.B: Retroactive interference is the correct answer. It refers specifically to the phenomenon in which newly acquired information works backward to disrupt retrieval of previously learned material, which precisely matches the student's experience of Spanish learning impairing French recall.
option_explanations.C: Encoding specificity refers to the principle that memory retrieval is enhanced when the conditions at retrieval match those present during encoding. It addresses context-dependent recall rather than the disruptive effect of new learning on old memories.
option_explanations.D: Decay theory proposes that memories fade over time simply due to disuse, without invoking the role of competing learned material. The student's difficulty is attributable to the specific introduction of new, similar content — not to the mere passage of time.

questions.source_summary: Retroactive interference occurs when more recently acquired information interferes with the ability to recall previously acquired information.
questions.vignette: Marcus, a 45-year-old bilingual attorney, has spoken Italian fluently since childhood. After relocating to Portugal for work, he spends six months intensively learning Portuguese, which he quickly masters. He is in good physical health and has no history of neurological issues. Upon returning to Italy for a family reunion, Marcus is surprised and frustrated to find that he struggles to retrieve previously memorized Italian phrases that had once come to him effortlessly, often producing Portuguese words instead.
questions.question: What memory phenomenon BEST accounts for Marcus's difficulty retrieving his long-established Italian vocabulary?

options.A: Retroactive interference
options.C: Proactive interference
options.D: State-dependent learning

option_explanations.A: Retroactive interference is correct. Marcus's intensive new learning of Portuguese — a structurally similar language — is disrupting his ability to retrieve his well-established Italian vocabulary, which is the defining pattern of retroactive interference: new learning impairing recall of prior learning.
option_explanations.B: Anterograde amnesia refers to the inability to form new memories following a neurological event, such as brain injury or surgery. Marcus has no neurological history, and his difficulty involves retrieving old memories rather than encoding new ones, ruling out this explanation.
option_explanations.C: Proactive interference would predict that Marcus's long-established Italian would disrupt his ability to learn or recall Portuguese — the opposite pattern from what is described. Here it is the newer Portuguese learning that is interfering with the older Italian material.
option_explanations.D: State-dependent learning holds that memory retrieval is facilitated when the internal physiological or psychological state at retrieval matches the state during encoding. Marcus's difficulty is not attributed to a mismatch in internal states but to the competing influence of newly learned, similar linguistic material.

questions.source_summary: Retroactive interference occurs when more recently acquired information interferes with the ability to recall previously acquired information.
questions.vignette: A research study examines memory performance in two groups of medical students who studied the same set of anatomical terms one month ago. Group A spent the past four weeks studying a completely unrelated subject — medical ethics. Group B spent the past four weeks studying a second, overlapping set of anatomical terms from a different body system. On the recall test for the original anatomical terms, Group A performs significantly better than Group B. The researchers note that both groups had equivalent initial learning of the original material and equivalent study time in the intervening period.
questions.question: Which memory phenomenon BEST explains the recall advantage of Group A over Group B?

options.A: Proactive interference reducing Group B's performance
options.B: Elaborative rehearsal improving Group A's retention
options.C: Retroactive interference impairing Group B's recall
options.D: Encoding specificity benefiting Group A's retrieval

option_explanations.C: Retroactive interference is correct. Group B studied new but overlapping anatomical content after encoding the original material, and this newer learning disrupted their ability to retrieve the original terms. Group A, by contrast, studied unrelated material that did not compete with the original memory traces, leading to better recall.
option_explanations.A: Proactive interference would describe the original anatomical terms disrupting Group B's ability to learn or recall the second set of anatomy studied — the forward direction. The scenario describes impaired recall of the original material due to what was learned afterward, which is the retroactive direction, not proactive.
option_explanations.B: Elaborative rehearsal refers to a depth-of-processing strategy in which learners connect new information to existing knowledge to enhance encoding. There is no indication that Group A used a deeper encoding strategy; both groups had equivalent initial learning, and the difference is explained by what they studied in the intervening period.
option_explanations.D: Encoding specificity predicts that recall is best when retrieval cues match the context of original encoding. This principle would apply if the test environment differed between groups, but the scenario provides no evidence of a contextual mismatch — both groups were tested under the same conditions.

questions.source_summary: Retroactive interference occurs when more recently acquired information interferes with the ability to recall previously acquired information.
questions.vignette: Dr. Patel, a neuropsychologist, evaluates a 28-year-old graduate student, Lena, who reports that she has been struggling to recall material from her first-year statistics courses since beginning her second-year advanced methods courses. Lena's performance on tasks assessing new learning is entirely intact, and her working memory scores are within normal limits. Crucially, when Lena is tested on her first-year statistics content in isolation — without any concurrent exposure to second-year material — her recall remains markedly below her baseline performance from the prior year. Dr. Patel notes that Lena's difficulties began precisely when the new courses introduced competing conceptual frameworks that substantially overlapped with the earlier material.
questions.question: Which phenomenon BEST explains Lena's selective difficulty with first-year statistics content?

options.A: Proactive interference from first-year content disrupting second-year learning
options.B: Retroactive interference from second-year learning disrupting first-year recall
options.C: Anterograde amnesia selectively affecting academic declarative memory
options.D: Context-dependent forgetting due to a mismatch in learning environments

option_explanations.A: Proactive interference describes a forward-acting disruption in which older material impairs recall of newer material. The scenario specifies that Lena's new learning is intact and that it is the first-year material that is impaired — the opposite temporal direction from proactive interference.
option_explanations.B: Retroactive interference is correct. The competing conceptual frameworks introduced in the second year are acting backward to disrupt Lena's ability to retrieve well-established first-year statistics content. The detail that new learning is intact and the impairment is selective to the older material is the diagnostic feature of retroactive interference.
option_explanations.C: Anterograde amnesia describes an inability to form new memories following a neurological event or injury, typically affecting episodic and declarative memory globally. Lena's new learning is explicitly intact, ruling out anterograde amnesia, and there is no indication of neurological compromise.
option_explanations.D: Context-dependent forgetting, grounded in encoding specificity, would predict that Lena struggles to recall first-year material because the retrieval environment differs from the original encoding context. However, the scenario specifies that Lena was tested on the first-year material in isolation, and the impairment is attributed to the introduction of competing overlapping content — not a change in environmental context.

questions.source_summary: Retroactive interference occurs when more recently acquired information interferes with the ability to recall previously acquired information.
questions.vignette: Elena spent several years mastering a complex set of wine-tasting descriptors for her sommelier certification, developing what colleagues described as an exceptional palate and near-flawless recall of regional wine profiles. After passing her certification, she accepted a position as a specialty tea evaluator and spent the following year deeply immersed in an equally detailed vocabulary for describing tea flavor profiles — categories that partially but not entirely overlapped with those she had used for wine. When Elena later returned to judging wine competitions, her fellow judges were puzzled to observe that she now made consistent errors in recalling specific regional wine descriptors she had once known without hesitation, despite the fact that she could flawlessly acquire and retain new tasting notes introduced at the competition. Her performance on completely unrelated tasks — such as recalling faces or life events — remained entirely normal.
questions.question: Which memory phenomenon BEST accounts for the pattern of Elena's recall failures?

options.A: Proactive interference from her wine training disrupting her tea evaluation performance
options.B: Context-dependent forgetting due to a shift from the wine-evaluation setting
options.C: Retroactive interference from tea training disrupting her wine descriptor recall
options.D: Encoding specificity failure due to changed internal state during retrieval

option_explanations.A: Proactive interference would predict that Elena's earlier wine training disrupts her ability to acquire or recall the newer tea descriptors — the forward direction. The scenario explicitly states the opposite pattern: Elena's tea training is what impaired her well-established wine recall. Furthermore, there is no indication her tea evaluation performance suffered from the wine knowledge.
option_explanations.B: Context-dependent forgetting would predict that Elena's recall failures stem from being tested in an environment that differs from the one in which she originally learned the wine descriptors. However, Elena is judging wine competitions — which closely resemble her original learning environment — and the scenario attributes the impairment to the introduction of a competing, overlapping knowledge domain rather than to a contextual mismatch.
option_explanations.C: Retroactive interference is correct. Elena's intensive acquisition of a partially overlapping tea-descriptor vocabulary acted backward to disrupt retrieval of her previously mastered wine descriptors. The key distinguishing details are: the newer domain is what is impairing the older one (not the reverse); new learning at the competition is intact; and the impairment is selective to the domain that competes with the tea material, leaving unrelated memory entirely normal.
option_explanations.D: Encoding specificity failure due to a changed internal state refers to state-dependent learning, in which memories encoded in a particular physiological or psychological state are best retrieved in that same state. There is no indication that Elena's internal state differed between encoding and retrieval, and the scenario's emphasis on a competing knowledge domain — rather than any internal state change — makes this explanation a poor fit.

questions.source_summary: Elaborative rehearsal, which involves making new information meaningful by relating it to something known or generating personally meaningful examples, is considered the most effective way to transfer new information from short- to long-term memory.
questions.vignette: A psychology professor teaches students a memorization strategy for learning the names of neurotransmitters. Rather than having students repeat the names over and over, she instructs them to connect each neurotransmitter to a personally meaningful example — for instance, linking dopamine to a time they felt excited about a reward. She explains that this strategy promotes transfer to long-term memory far more effectively than simple repetition. Students who use this approach during elaborative rehearsal consistently outperform peers who rely solely on rote repetition on later recall tests.
questions.question: Which memory strategy is best illustrated by the professor's instructional approach?

options.A: Maintenance rehearsal
options.C: Encoding specificity
options.D: Spaced practice

option_explanations.A: Maintenance rehearsal involves repeating information verbatim to keep it active in short-term memory without creating meaningful connections; the professor explicitly contrasts her approach against this type of repetition, making it incorrect here.
option_explanations.B: Elaborative rehearsal is precisely the strategy of connecting new information to existing knowledge or personally meaningful examples to facilitate transfer into long-term memory, which is exactly what the professor is teaching.
option_explanations.C: Encoding specificity refers to the principle that memory retrieval is best when the context at retrieval matches the context at encoding; it describes a retrieval condition rather than a rehearsal strategy used to strengthen initial encoding.
option_explanations.D: Spaced practice (the spacing effect) involves distributing study sessions over time to improve long-term retention; while effective, it refers to the scheduling of practice rather than the cognitive depth at which information is processed.

questions.source_summary: Elaborative rehearsal, which involves making new information meaningful by relating it to something known or generating personally meaningful examples, is considered the most effective way to transfer new information from short- to long-term memory.
questions.vignette: A 22-year-old college student with a history of test anxiety is preparing for his anatomy final. His tutor, who notes that the student tends to rush through material, encourages him to stop passively rereading his notes and instead think about how each muscle group relates to sports movements he already knows from playing soccer. The student, despite his anxiety, finds that when he uses this approach he can recall structures days later without additional review. The tutor explains that forming meaningful connections between new and existing knowledge is the key reason this strategy transfers information so durably into long-term memory.
questions.question: Which memory encoding strategy does the tutor's recommendation best exemplify?

options.A: State-dependent learning
options.C: Elaborative rehearsal
options.D: Retroactive interference reduction

option_explanations.A: State-dependent learning describes the phenomenon in which memory retrieval is enhanced when the learner's internal state (e.g., mood, arousal) at retrieval matches the state at encoding; the tutor is not manipulating the student's internal state but rather the depth of processing applied to new material.
option_explanations.B: Maintenance rehearsal consists of repeating information without adding meaning, keeping it briefly in short-term memory; the tutor explicitly advises the student to move away from this passive re-reading approach.
option_explanations.C: Elaborative rehearsal involves linking new information to personally meaningful prior knowledge, which is precisely what the tutor advocates when asking the student to connect muscle groups to familiar soccer movements, thereby promoting durable long-term storage.
option_explanations.D: Retroactive interference reduction refers to minimizing the disruption that newly learned material causes to previously learned material; it concerns the interference among memory traces rather than the encoding strategy used to create them.

questions.source_summary: Elaborative rehearsal, which involves making new information meaningful by relating it to something known or generating personally meaningful examples, is considered the most effective way to transfer new information from short- to long-term memory.
questions.vignette: A clinical supervisor notices that her practicum students consistently forget the diagnostic criteria they study the night before supervision meetings. She redesigns the learning activity: instead of assigning the students to read the criteria repeatedly, she has them write a brief case description of a fictional client who would meet each criterion, drawing on their own clinical experiences. Students who initially resisted the change — arguing it took more time — later report that the criteria feel 'locked in' and effortless to retrieve during sessions. The supervisor attributes the improvement to the deeper level of encoding achieved when learners actively relate new material to things they already know.
questions.question: The improvement in retention described by the supervisor is most directly attributable to which memory process?

options.A: Spaced retrieval practice
options.C: Elaborative rehearsal
options.D: Proactive interference reduction

option_explanations.A: Spaced retrieval practice involves testing oneself at increasing intervals and benefits memory through repeated retrieval attempts over time; while the new activity does involve active processing, the key mechanism described is meaning-making and connection to prior knowledge, not distributed retrieval testing.
option_explanations.B: Encoding specificity holds that memory is best retrieved when cues present at encoding are also present at retrieval; the supervisor's explanation focuses on depth of processing and personal relevance rather than matching retrieval contexts to encoding contexts, making this a plausible but incorrect choice.
option_explanations.C: Elaborative rehearsal is the process of making new material meaningful by connecting it to existing knowledge or generating personally relevant examples; writing case descriptions based on clinical experience is a textbook instance of this process, explaining the durable improvement in retrieval.
option_explanations.D: Proactive interference occurs when older memories disrupt the learning of newer material; reducing it would improve learning, but the vignette describes no prior competing memories and the mechanism offered by the supervisor is about enriching encoding, not clearing old interference.

questions.source_summary: Elaborative rehearsal, which involves making new information meaningful by relating it to something known or generating personally meaningful examples, is considered the most effective way to transfer new information from short- to long-term memory.
questions.vignette: A memory researcher compares two groups of nursing students learning pharmacology. Both groups study the same material for the same amount of time and in the same quiet room. Group A reviews flashcards by reading each drug name and its side effect profile aloud three times. Group B is instructed to pause after reading each card and briefly consider why a patient with a specific health history they have personally encountered would or would not tolerate that drug. On a surprise recall test one week later, Group B significantly outperforms Group A, even though both groups reported equal subjective confidence immediately after studying. The researcher concludes that the difference is not explained by time-on-task, environmental context, or prior knowledge differences between groups.
questions.question: Which encoding principle most directly explains Group B's superior retention at the one-week follow-up?

options.A: Encoding specificity
options.C: Generation effect
options.D: Elaborative rehearsal

option_explanations.A: Encoding specificity predicts that recall is best when retrieval cues match encoding cues; since both groups studied in the same environment and were tested in the same environment, contextual cue matching is controlled for and cannot explain the between-group difference.
option_explanations.B: The distributed practice effect predicts that spacing study sessions over time improves retention compared to massed practice; both groups studied for the same duration in a single session, so distribution of practice is not the differentiating variable here.
option_explanations.C: The generation effect refers to the memory advantage for information that a learner generates or produces themselves rather than reads passively; while Group B does engage more actively, the specific mechanism described — connecting new drug information to personally meaningful patient scenarios — is the defining feature of elaborative rehearsal rather than mere generation.
option_explanations.D: Elaborative rehearsal explains Group B's advantage: by actively relating each drug's profile to a personally meaningful clinical scenario, Group B created richer, more interconnected memory traces, facilitating durable long-term storage in a way that Group A's repetitive reading did not.

questions.source_summary: Elaborative rehearsal, which involves making new information meaningful by relating it to something known or generating personally meaningful examples, is considered the most effective way to transfer new information from short- to long-term memory.
questions.vignette: A graduate student preparing for a comprehensive exam tries two different approaches across two study sessions held on separate days. In the first session, she goes through her notes and reads each concept aloud several times until it feels familiar, finishing in 90 minutes and feeling confident. In the second session, she spends the same 90 minutes on new material but forces herself to stop after each concept and write a brief story about a person she knows whose behavior or life circumstance illustrates that concept. She finds the second session more effortful and initially doubts it is working. On the exam three weeks later, she recalls almost none of the material from the first session but retrieves nearly all the material from the second session with ease, even though the two sessions were identical in length, physical location, and time of day.
questions.question: Which process most directly accounts for the student's superior retention of material from the second study session?

options.A: State-dependent learning
options.C: The spacing effect
options.D: Retroactive interference

option_explanations.A: State-dependent learning predicts that memory retrieval is enhanced when the learner's internal state at test matches the state during encoding; because both sessions occurred at the same time of day in the same location, internal state differences are not a distinguishing factor, and the vignette describes no mood or arousal differences between sessions that would favor this explanation.
option_explanations.B: Elaborative rehearsal is the process of making new information meaningful by connecting it to personally relevant knowledge or generating illustrative examples; the student's deliberate effort to link each concept to a real person she knows is a precise description of this strategy, explaining why those memories survived over three weeks while the verbally repeated material did not.
option_explanations.C: The spacing effect predicts better long-term retention when study sessions are distributed over time rather than massed; although the two sessions were on separate days, the question concerns the difference in retention between material within those sessions, not the scheduling across them, so spacing does not explain why second-session material was retained and first-session material was not.
option_explanations.D: Retroactive interference occurs when newly learned material disrupts retrieval of previously learned material; while the student does learn new material in the second session after the first, retroactive interference would predict poorer recall for the first session's material — which is observed — but it cannot explain why the second session's material is so well retained, as it addresses forgetting rather than the mechanism of durable encoding.

questions.source_summary: Baddeley's multi-component model of working memory consists of a central executive and three subsystems: a phonological loop, a visuo-spatial sketchpad, and an episodic buffer.
questions.vignette: A cognitive psychologist is explaining to her graduate seminar how people temporarily hold and manipulate information during complex tasks. She describes a supervisory system called the central executive that coordinates attention and delegates work to specialized subsystems. One of these subsystems, the phonological loop, handles verbal and auditory information, while another, the visuo-spatial sketchpad, manages mental imagery and spatial relationships. A third component, the episodic buffer, integrates information from the other subsystems with long-term memory. She notes that this framework has guided decades of research on reading, arithmetic, and clinical populations.
questions.question: Which theoretical model of memory is the psychologist describing?

options.A: Atkinson–Shiffrin multi-store model
options.C: Cowan's embedded-process model
options.D: Levels-of-processing framework

option_explanations.A: The Atkinson–Shiffrin model posits three stores — sensory, short-term, and long-term memory — governed by rehearsal processes, but it does not include a central executive, phonological loop, or visuo-spatial sketchpad as distinct named components. The vignette's four-component architecture is not consistent with this model.
option_explanations.B: Baddeley's multi-component working memory model is precisely defined by a central executive plus three subsystems: the phonological loop, the visuo-spatial sketchpad, and the episodic buffer. All four components are explicitly named in the vignette, making this the correct identification.
option_explanations.C: Cowan's embedded-process model describes working memory as activated portions of long-term memory with a capacity-limited focus of attention, but it does not subdivide storage into a phonological loop and visuo-spatial sketchpad as separate, named slave systems. The vignette's structure does not match this framework.
option_explanations.D: The levels-of-processing framework (Craik & Lockhart) argues that memory durability depends on the depth of encoding — shallow phonemic vs. deep semantic processing — rather than specifying distinct subsystems. It does not propose a central executive or named storage buffers.

questions.source_summary: Baddeley's multi-component model of working memory consists of a central executive and three subsystems: a phonological loop, a visuo-spatial sketchpad, and an episodic buffer.
questions.vignette: A neuropsychologist is assessing a 58-year-old retired teacher following a mild stroke in the left prefrontal region. The patient performs well on long-term recall tasks but struggles whenever she must simultaneously hold and manipulate information — for example, mentally reversing a sequence of digits while tracking a conversation. Testing reveals that she has particular difficulty on tasks requiring her to blend verbal and spatial information into a unified scene, a function attributed to the episodic buffer in working memory research. Her performance on pure verbal repetition tasks is only mildly impaired, and her spatial visualization in isolation is also largely intact. The neuropsychologist frames the deficits using a well-established multi-component model of working memory.
questions.question: The neuropsychologist is applying which model of memory to interpret this patient's pattern of deficits?

options.A: Tulving's encoding specificity principle
options.C: Baddeley's multi-component working memory model
options.D: Cowan's embedded-process model

option_explanations.A: Tulving's encoding specificity principle states that retrieval is most successful when cues present at retrieval match those present at encoding; it does not describe subsystems for holding and manipulating information online. The patient's deficit in simultaneous maintenance and manipulation is not explained by this principle.
option_explanations.B: The Atkinson–Shiffrin model distinguishes sensory, short-term, and long-term stores but treats short-term memory as a unitary buffer and does not propose a separate episodic buffer or visuo-spatial sketchpad. The vignette's reference to the episodic buffer and the dissociation between verbal and spatial subsystems are hallmarks of Baddeley's model, not Atkinson–Shiffrin.
option_explanations.C: Baddeley's multi-component model explicitly includes the episodic buffer as the subsystem that integrates verbal and spatial information into coherent, multidimensional representations. The patient's selective difficulty blending inputs from the phonological and visuo-spatial subsystems, while each subsystem alone is relatively intact, directly maps onto this framework.
option_explanations.D: Cowan's embedded-process model emphasizes a capacity-limited focus of attention operating over activated long-term memory representations; it does not use the terminology of an episodic buffer or distinguish slave subsystems as Baddeley does. The neuropsychologist's explicit reference to the episodic buffer is incompatible with Cowan's architecture.

questions.source_summary: Baddeley's multi-component model of working memory consists of a central executive and three subsystems: a phonological loop, a visuo-spatial sketchpad, and an episodic buffer.
questions.vignette: A research team studying cognitive load in air-traffic controllers notices that controllers make the most errors not when they are tracking many aircraft simultaneously on radar — a highly visual task — nor when they are repeating clearance instructions verbatim, but rather when they must switch rapidly between those two demands while also deciding which aircraft to prioritize. One controller with decades of experience explains that each individual task feels manageable, but coordinating all of them at once feels like 'running out of mental bandwidth.' A researcher notes that this bottleneck appears to reside in the system responsible for allocating attentional resources and switching between tasks, rather than in any domain-specific storage component. Interestingly, the controllers scored normally on isolated tests of spatial memory and verbal recall, suggesting the storage subsystems themselves are intact.
questions.question: The cognitive bottleneck experienced by the controllers is best explained by which component of Baddeley's working memory model?

options.A: Phonological loop
options.C: Visuo-spatial sketchpad
options.D: Central executive

option_explanations.A: The phonological loop temporarily stores and rehearses verbal and auditory information. While the controllers do handle verbal clearance instructions, the bottleneck described is not in storing verbal material per se — verbal recall in isolation is intact — but in coordinating multiple tasks simultaneously. The phonological loop does not manage attentional switching between subsystems.
option_explanations.B: The episodic buffer integrates information from the phonological loop, visuo-spatial sketchpad, and long-term memory into a unified, multidimensional episode. Although integration is involved in the controllers' work, the specific deficit described is attentional resource allocation and task-switching — an executive function — not the binding of multimodal information into coherent scenes.
option_explanations.C: The visuo-spatial sketchpad supports mental imagery and spatial tracking, which is indeed used in monitoring radar displays. However, spatial memory in isolation is described as intact for these controllers, so the sketchpad itself is not the locus of the bottleneck. The problem arises when coordinating across tasks, not when doing spatial work alone.
option_explanations.D: The central executive is Baddeley's supervisory attentional component responsible for controlling and coordinating the slave subsystems, shifting attention between tasks, and managing dual-task performance. The controllers' breakdown occurs specifically when switching between verbal and spatial demands while making priority decisions — a classic central executive load — while isolated subsystem performance remains normal.

questions.source_summary: Baddeley's multi-component model of working memory consists of a central executive and three subsystems: a phonological loop, a visuo-spatial sketchpad, and an episodic buffer.
questions.vignette: During a dual-task experiment, participants are asked to navigate a virtual maze while simultaneously solving verbal anagrams. A researcher observes that performance on each task degrades significantly when the two tasks are combined, but crucially, the interference is asymmetric: maze navigation suffers far more than anagram solving. When a third group is asked to navigate the maze while repeating a simple, meaningless phrase aloud (articulatory suppression), maze performance does not decline further compared to navigation alone. The researcher concludes that the two primary tasks drew on overlapping resources within one type of subsystem but not the other, and that binding the outputs of these subsystems into a coherent mental workspace involves yet a third component beyond either storage subsystem.
questions.question: The researcher's conclusion about why the tasks interfere with each other is most consistent with which theoretical framework?

options.A: Atkinson–Shiffrin multi-store model, specifically the limited capacity of the short-term store
options.B: Baddeley's multi-component working memory model, specifically the distinction between the visuo-spatial sketchpad and the phonological loop
options.C: Cowan's embedded-process model, specifically the capacity limit of the focus of attention
options.D: Levels-of-processing framework, specifically that deeper encoding of spatial routes competes with verbal processing

option_explanations.A: The Atkinson–Shiffrin model treats short-term memory as a single, unitary store; it cannot explain why two tasks that are both active in short-term memory would produce asymmetric interference with a domain-specific pattern. If capacity were the only issue, adding articulatory suppression should compete with both tasks equally, which the data do not support.
option_explanations.B: Baddeley's model posits separate subsystems: the visuo-spatial sketchpad for spatial navigation and the phonological loop for verbal material. The asymmetric interference — maze navigation disrupted by anagrams but not by articulatory suppression alone — indicates that both tasks load the visuo-spatial sketchpad (since navigating and solving anagrams requiring mental manipulation of letter arrangements may share spatial resources), while pure articulatory suppression taxes only the phonological loop. The mention of binding outputs into a coherent workspace points to the episodic buffer as a third component, consistent with Baddeley's architecture.
option_explanations.C: Cowan's embedded-process model proposes a single focus of attention with a capacity of approximately four chunks, without distinguishing domain-specific slave subsystems. It would predict symmetric interference whenever two tasks exceed attentional capacity, and it cannot account for the domain-specific pattern where articulatory suppression does not add to maze interference — a dissociation that requires separate verbal and spatial storage components.
option_explanations.D: The levels-of-processing framework addresses encoding depth and long-term retention, not the real-time management of concurrent tasks in temporary storage. It provides no mechanism for explaining why two simultaneously performed tasks interfere selectively based on their content domain, nor does it predict that articulatory suppression would spare spatial performance.

questions.source_summary: Baddeley's multi-component model of working memory consists of a central executive and three subsystems: a phonological loop, a visuo-spatial sketchpad, and an episodic buffer.
questions.vignette: A researcher presents volunteers with a task in which they must hold a short melody in mind while simultaneously rotating a three-dimensional object in their imagination. She notices that when she adds a fourth task — having participants continuously murmur a repeated nonsense syllable — it disrupts how well they remember the melody but has almost no effect on their ability to rotate the object. She also observes that when participants are asked afterward to explain what they were thinking about during the tasks, they often describe a coherent mental scene in which the sounds and shapes seemed to 'come together' as a single experience, even though they had been given those pieces separately. A colleague suggests the results reveal a system with at least three distinct components that operate in parallel and are coordinated by a fourth, supervisory layer.
questions.question: Which model of memory is most directly supported by the full pattern of findings described in this study?

options.A: Tulving's encoding specificity principle, because the match between encoding conditions and retrieval cues determines which elements are recalled together
options.B: Cowan's embedded-process model, because a capacity-limited focus of attention selectively activates some representations while others remain in the background
options.C: Baddeley's multi-component working memory model, because separate domain-specific storage buffers, a binding component, and an attentional control system together explain the full pattern
options.D: Atkinson–Shiffrin multi-store model, because limited rehearsal capacity in the short-term store explains why adding a concurrent task impairs retention of the melody

option_explanations.A: Encoding specificity predicts better retrieval when retrieval conditions match encoding conditions — it is a principle about long-term memory access, not about how information is concurrently held and manipulated in real time. It cannot account for why articulatory interference selectively disrupts melody retention but not object rotation, nor does it predict the spontaneous integration of separately presented auditory and spatial information during active processing.
option_explanations.B: Cowan's model uses a single focus of attention without domain-specific slave systems, predicting that any two concurrent tasks should compete for the same attentional resource. This model cannot explain the selective disruption pattern: if the focus of attention were the bottleneck, murmuring a nonsense syllable should impair both melody retention and object rotation equally. The model also does not include a dedicated binding component like the episodic buffer to explain participants' unified multisensory experience.
option_explanations.C: The full pattern of findings maps precisely onto Baddeley's model. The selective disruption of melody (but not rotation) by articulatory suppression reveals separate verbal (phonological loop) and spatial (visuo-spatial sketchpad) subsystems that can be independently loaded. The spontaneous integration of auditory and visual-spatial information into a unified conscious scene points to the episodic buffer as the binding component. The colleague's description of a supervisory layer coordinating three parallel components reflects the central executive. No other listed model accounts for all three observations simultaneously.
option_explanations.D: The Atkinson–Shiffrin model's short-term store is a unitary rehearsal buffer, so it predicts that any additional task competing for rehearsal resources would impair both the melody and the object rotation comparably. The selective effect of articulatory suppression only on melody retention, while spatial rotation remains unaffected, is inexplicable within a single-store framework. Furthermore, this model has no mechanism for the spontaneous binding of separately presented auditory and spatial information into an integrated experience.

questions.source_summary: The "mediator effectiveness hypothesis" is most useful for understanding the "testing effect," which is the increased ability to remember information when learning includes both studying and repeated opportunities to retrieve the information (Pyc & Rawson, 2010).
questions.vignette: A cognitive psychologist conducts a study in which one group of students studies a list of word pairs and then repeatedly takes practice tests on the material, while a control group spends the same total time only re-reading the pairs. At a delayed recall assessment one week later, the practice-test group significantly outperforms the re-study group. The researcher explains the superiority of the practice-test group by arguing that repeated retrieval practice strengthens the mediators — the mental connections linking cue words to target words — making them more accessible during the final test. This account, focused on how well the linking mechanism holds up under retrieval demands, is used to explain why the testing effect emerges. The researcher concludes that mediator effectiveness, not mere exposure, drives the advantage.
questions.question: Which theoretical account BEST explains why the practice-test group outperformed the re-study group at delayed recall?

options.A: Elaborative rehearsal
options.C: Mediator effectiveness hypothesis
options.D: Spacing effect

option_explanations.A: Elaborative rehearsal refers to processing new information by connecting it to existing knowledge to create deeper, more meaningful memory traces. While it shares the idea of richer encoding, it does not specifically address how the strength of retrieval mediators improves across repeated test opportunities, which is the focus here.
option_explanations.B: The encoding specificity principle holds that retrieval is most successful when the context at retrieval matches the context at encoding. Although it addresses retrieval success, it does not explain the mechanism by which repeated testing strengthens the link between cue and target — the core claim of the mediator effectiveness hypothesis.
option_explanations.C: The mediator effectiveness hypothesis (Pyc & Rawson, 2010) proposes that repeated retrieval practice enhances the testing effect because each successful retrieval strengthens the mental mediator connecting the cue to the target word, making that link more durable and accessible on later tests. This directly accounts for the pattern described.
option_explanations.D: The spacing effect refers to the well-documented finding that distributed practice over time leads to better long-term retention than massed practice. Although spacing and testing are related phenomena, the spacing effect does not specifically address the role of mediator strength in explaining why retrieval practice outperforms re-study.

questions.vignette: Dr. Osei is a graduate student in cognitive psychology who is designing a memory study to examine why repeatedly being tested on material leads to better long-term retention compared to simply re-reading it. She is particularly interested in the role of the mental 'bridges' that learners generate to link a cue word to its target word during each practice attempt, and whether the quality and robustness of those bridges predicts final recall accuracy. Notably, many of her participants are older adults, a detail she controls for statistically. She concludes that the advantage of repeated testing is best explained by how well those cue-target links hold up across successive retrieval attempts rather than by increased overall study time.
questions.question: Which theoretical framework is Dr. Osei's study MOST directly testing?

options.A: Transfer-appropriate processing
options.C: Levels-of-processing framework
options.D: Desirable difficulties framework

option_explanations.A: Transfer-appropriate processing proposes that memory performance is maximized when the cognitive processes used at retrieval match those used at encoding. Although it involves retrieval, it emphasizes process-matching between study and test rather than the progressive strengthening of mediating links across repeated test trials.
option_explanations.B: The mediator effectiveness hypothesis specifically proposes that the testing effect arises because each retrieval attempt strengthens the mental bridge connecting the cue to the target, making those mediators more robust and accessible over time. Dr. Osei's focus on the quality and durability of cue-target 'bridges' across repeated retrievals maps precisely onto this account.
option_explanations.C: The levels-of-processing framework (Craik & Lockhart) holds that deeper, more meaningful encoding leads to better retention than shallow processing. While it is relevant to how well information is initially encoded, it does not speak to the specific mechanism by which repeated retrieval trials improve memory beyond initial study.
option_explanations.D: The desirable difficulties framework (Bjork) is a broader account of learning conditions — including testing, spacing, and interleaving — that are challenging during acquisition but promote long-term retention. It provides an umbrella concept but does not specifically identify mediator strength as the mechanism explaining why repeated testing outperforms re-study.

questions.source_summary: The "mediator effectiveness hypothesis" is most useful for understanding the "testing effect," which is the increased ability to remember information when learning includes both studying and repeated opportunities to retrieve the information (Pyc & Rawson, 2010).
questions.vignette: A memory researcher notices that students who take multiple low-stakes quizzes throughout a semester consistently outperform students who spend the same amount of time re-reading their notes, even though both groups report equal confidence before the final exam. Intrigued, the researcher designs a follow-up experiment using paired associates in which participants generate their own linking phrases between cue and target words; critically, the researcher tracks whether the same linking phrase is successfully accessed on each of three successive retrieval attempts. Results show that when the same linking phrase is recalled reliably across attempts, final retention is substantially higher — and this link reliability, not the sheer number of exposures, statistically mediates the recall advantage. The researcher cautions that the effect is distinct from any advantage conferred simply by distributing study sessions over time.
questions.question: Which memory phenomenon and its proposed underlying mechanism are BEST captured by the researcher's findings?

options.A: The spacing effect, explained by deficient processing theory
options.C: The testing effect, explained by the mediator effectiveness hypothesis
options.D: The generation effect, explained by enhanced distinctiveness

option_explanations.A: The spacing effect refers to the mnemonic advantage of distributing study sessions over time, and deficient processing theory explains it by arguing that massed repetitions receive less cognitive effort. The researcher explicitly rules out distributed study time as the explanation, and the focus on mediator reliability across successive retrieval trials does not match the spacing effect's mechanism.
option_explanations.B: Elaborative rehearsal involves deep, meaningful encoding by linking new material to existing knowledge. While the generation of linking phrases resembles elaborative rehearsal, the key finding here is not about encoding depth but about how reliably that linking phrase is accessed across repeated retrieval attempts — a distinction central to the mediator effectiveness hypothesis.
option_explanations.C: The testing effect is the finding that repeated retrieval practice leads to better long-term retention than re-study alone. The mediator effectiveness hypothesis explains this by proposing that each successful retrieval strengthens the associative link (mediator) between cue and target, and that mediator reliability across attempts drives the retention advantage — precisely what the statistical mediation analysis demonstrated.
option_explanations.D: The generation effect is the finding that items generated by the learner (rather than read passively) are better remembered, attributed to enhanced processing or distinctiveness. Although participants here do generate linking phrases, the critical manipulation is the consistency of mediator access across multiple retrievals, not the act of generation per se, making this explanation insufficient.

questions.source_summary: The "mediator effectiveness hypothesis" is most useful for understanding the "testing effect," which is the increased ability to remember information when learning includes both studying and repeated opportunities to retrieve the information (Pyc & Rawson, 2010).
questions.vignette: A research team studying long-term retention asks two groups to learn Swahili-English word pairs over the course of a week. The first group cycles through the list with repeated study opportunities, while the second group takes a brief cued-recall test after each presentation and must produce the English equivalent given the Swahili cue. Strikingly, the study-only group performs slightly better on an immediate test administered the same day, but the test group shows dramatically superior recall at a one-week delay. Post-session interviews reveal that learners in the test group consistently report being able to 'pull up' a specific associative image or phrase that connects the two words, and this subjective report of link accessibility predicts their one-week recall scores better than any other variable measured. The team concludes that the short-term disadvantage of the test group is simply a cost of the conditions that produce durable associative pathways.
questions.question: The mechanism the research team identifies as PRIMARILY responsible for the one-week recall advantage is BEST described by which of the following?

options.A: Desirable difficulties, mediated by increased cognitive effort during retrieval attempts
options.B: The spacing effect, mediated by consolidation processes activated by distributed practice
options.C: Transfer-appropriate processing, mediated by matching retrieval conditions to encoding conditions
options.D: The testing effect, mediated by the strengthening of the cue-to-target mediating link across repeated retrieval

option_explanations.A: Desirable difficulties is a valid overarching framework that encompasses testing and spacing as conditions that introduce short-term challenges for long-term gain — and the initial disadvantage of the test group could plausibly fit this description. However, desirable difficulties is a general umbrella rather than a mechanistic account; it does not specify that durable associative links (mediators) are what is being strengthened, which is the precise explanatory variable identified by the research team.
option_explanations.B: The spacing effect and consolidation-based accounts could explain a delayed recall advantage if the two groups had differing inter-trial intervals. However, the design does not manipulate spacing — both groups encounter material across the same week-long window. The distinguishing finding is that subjective accessibility of a specific associative link, not distributed timing, predicts one-week recall, ruling out spacing as the primary mechanism.
option_explanations.C: Transfer-appropriate processing would predict that the test group's advantage arises because their study conditions match the final recall test format (cued recall in both cases). This is a defensible alternative, but it does not account for the specific finding that the accessibility of an associative link — not merely format congruence — is the strongest predictor of delayed retention, which points instead to the mediator effectiveness hypothesis.
option_explanations.D: The mediator effectiveness hypothesis holds that repeated retrieval practice strengthens the mental link connecting the retrieval cue to the target, and that the durability of this mediator across practice trials is the mechanism underlying the testing effect. The finding that subjective accessibility of a specific associative pathway independently predicts one-week recall — beyond other variables — is the hallmark prediction of this hypothesis, making this the best answer.

questions.vignette: A professor notices that students in her course who write out answers to practice questions from memory — even when they frequently struggle and sometimes fail to produce the answer at all — score substantially higher on cumulative end-of-term exams than classmates who spend an equivalent amount of time re-reading highlighted passages. Curious about why this occurs, she interviews both groups and finds that the high-performing students almost universally describe a specific mental 'shortcut' or 'bridge' that helps them arrive at the answer — and those who describe the same bridge consistently across multiple practice sessions do even better than those whose bridge changes or disappears between sessions. Interestingly, the professor initially attributes the gap to the fact that the practice-question students spread their studying across more days, but a careful analysis reveals that session timing is unrelated to final scores once the consistency of the mental bridge is taken into account. She also considers whether the students who write answers are simply paying closer attention or processing material more deeply, but measures of subjective effort and comprehension ratings at study do not differ between groups.
questions.question: Which theoretical account MOST precisely explains the pattern the professor has identified?

options.A: The spacing effect: distributing practice across sessions strengthens memory consolidation more than massed re-reading
options.B: Levels-of-processing: the act of generating written answers requires deeper semantic processing than passive re-reading
options.C: The testing effect explained by the mediator effectiveness hypothesis: repeated active retrieval stabilizes the mental link between a cue and its target, and it is the consistency of that link — not study time or processing depth — that drives superior long-term retention
options.D: Desirable difficulties: the increased challenge of producing answers from memory engages effortful processing that produces more durable memory traces regardless of any specific linking mechanism

option_explanations.A: The spacing effect is a strong initial candidate because students in the practice-question group might naturally distribute their studying more than re-readers. However, the professor's analysis directly rules out session timing as an explanatory variable once bridge consistency is controlled, demonstrating that the temporal distribution of practice is not the active ingredient — eliminating the spacing effect as the primary account.
option_explanations.B: Levels-of-processing is also plausible because generating answers from memory is arguably a deeper, more effortful cognitive operation than passive re-reading. However, the professor specifically measured subjective effort and comprehension at encoding and found no difference between groups, and the key predictor is the consistency of a specific mental link across sessions rather than processing depth at a single study episode — ruling out a pure levels-of-processing explanation.
option_explanations.C: The mediator effectiveness hypothesis explains the testing effect by proposing that repeated retrieval of a specific cue-to-target link strengthens that mental mediator over time, and that the reliability of that mediator across practice trials — not mere repetition, spacing, or encoding depth — is what produces durable long-term retention. The professor's finding that consistent bridge accessibility, independent of timing and effort, predicts final exam scores maps precisely onto this mechanistic account.
option_explanations.D: Desirable difficulties is a compelling alternative because it captures the intuition that the struggle of generating answers from memory is itself beneficial. However, desirable difficulties is a framework-level description rather than a specific mechanism, and it does not predict that the consistency of a particular associative pathway across attempts (rather than effort per se) would be the strongest predictor of retention — making it less precise than the mediator effectiveness hypothesis for explaining the pattern observed.

questions.source_summary: Jenny J.'s study investigates the effects of retroactive interference, which occurs when recently learned information interferes with the ability to recall previously learned information.
questions.vignette: A researcher asks participants to memorize a list of Spanish vocabulary words. Half the participants then learn a list of Italian vocabulary words, while the other half rest quietly. When both groups are tested on the original Spanish list, the group that learned Italian vocabulary performs significantly worse than the resting group. The researcher concludes that the new information disrupted recall of the previously learned material.
questions.question: Which memory phenomenon best explains why participants who learned Italian vocabulary recalled fewer Spanish words than those who rested?

options.A: Proactive interference
options.C: Encoding specificity
options.D: State-dependent learning

option_explanations.A: Proactive interference occurs when older, previously learned information disrupts recall of newer material — the opposite direction. Here, the Italian list (newer) is disrupting recall of the Spanish list (older), so proactive interference does not apply.
option_explanations.B: Retroactive interference occurs when newly learned information impairs the ability to recall previously learned information. The Italian vocabulary (new) disrupted recall of the Spanish vocabulary (old), which is the defining pattern of retroactive interference.
option_explanations.C: Encoding specificity refers to the principle that memory is best when retrieval conditions match encoding conditions. There is no mention of a mismatch between learning and testing contexts, so this principle does not account for the finding.
option_explanations.D: State-dependent learning describes enhanced recall when one's internal physiological or emotional state at retrieval matches the state at encoding. No information about internal states is provided, making this an incorrect explanation.

questions.vignette: Marcus, a 22-year-old bilingual college student, studied French grammar rules thoroughly before his final exam. The night before the exam, he also completed several hours of mandatory Spanish grammar exercises for a different course. Although Marcus felt confident about French before the Spanish practice, he struggled to recall many French rules during the exam the next morning. His professor noted that despite Marcus's strong motivation and prior language experience, his recall of the earlier-studied material was significantly impaired by the intervening material he studied afterward.
questions.question: What memory process most directly accounts for Marcus's difficulty recalling French grammar rules after practicing Spanish grammar?

options.A: Retroactive interference
options.C: Elaborative rehearsal failure
options.D: Decay theory

option_explanations.A: Retroactive interference occurs when subsequently learned material disrupts retrieval of previously learned information. Marcus's Spanish grammar practice (new learning) impaired his recall of French grammar rules (earlier learning), which fits this pattern precisely.
option_explanations.B: Proactive interference occurs when earlier-learned information disrupts recall of later-learned information. In this scenario the impairment runs in the opposite direction — the Spanish material disrupted French, not the other way around — so proactive interference is incorrect.
option_explanations.C: Elaborative rehearsal failure refers to insufficient deep or meaningful processing of information at encoding. Marcus had thoroughly studied French before the problem arose, so the issue is not one of inadequate encoding but of subsequent interference at retrieval.
option_explanations.D: Decay theory proposes that memories fade passively over time due to disuse. The time elapsed between Marcus's French study and the exam was brief, and a competing learning event — not mere time — produced the impairment, ruling out simple decay.

questions.vignette: Dr. Patel is evaluating a research assistant who mastered a complex lab protocol six months ago and performed it flawlessly at that time. Recently, the lab switched to a revised protocol, and the assistant spent two weeks training on it. When asked to demonstrate the original protocol for a visiting auditor, the assistant made repeated errors on steps she had previously performed automatically, yet executed the new protocol without difficulty. Dr. Patel noted that the assistant's long-term exposure to the original protocol rules out any explanation based on weak initial learning, and the time gap alone seems insufficient to explain the level of forgetting.
questions.question: Which memory phenomenon best explains the research assistant's difficulty with the original protocol after learning the revised one?

options.A: Proactive interference
options.C: Retroactive interference
options.D: Anterograde amnesia

option_explanations.A: Proactive interference occurs when previously learned information disrupts recall of newer information. Here it is the original protocol (old) that cannot be recalled, while the new protocol is intact — the disruption travels backward to older material, which is the opposite of what proactive interference predicts.
option_explanations.B: Encoding specificity holds that recall is best when retrieval cues match encoding conditions. The scenario gives no indication that the context or cues present during original learning are absent during recall; the disruption is attributable to a competing learned procedure, not a contextual mismatch.
option_explanations.C: Retroactive interference occurs when newly acquired information disrupts recall of previously learned material. The assistant's two weeks of training on the revised protocol (new learning) impaired her retrieval of the original protocol (old learning), which is precisely the retroactive interference pattern. The vignette rules out weak encoding and passive decay, pointing to active backward interference.
option_explanations.D: Anterograde amnesia refers to the inability to form new memories following brain injury or neurological insult. The assistant successfully learned the new protocol, demonstrating intact new memory formation, so anterograde amnesia does not apply.

questions.vignette: A cognitive psychologist designs a study in which Group A learns a set of paired associates and then immediately learns a second, highly similar set before sleeping. Group B learns the same initial paired associates but spends the intervening period on an unrelated arithmetic task before sleeping. Both groups sleep the same number of hours, and sleep architecture measures confirm comparable consolidation periods across groups. The next morning, Group A recalls significantly fewer items from the first paired-associate list than Group B, despite equivalent performance immediately after initial learning and equivalent sleep. The researcher argues the data challenge any account that attributes the forgetting solely to the passage of time or to neurological consolidation processes.
questions.question: The pattern of results in this study is most consistent with which memory phenomenon?

options.A: Proactive interference
options.C: Motivated forgetting
options.D: Retroactive interference

option_explanations.A: Proactive interference predicts that the first learned list would disrupt recall of the second list, not that the second list would disrupt recall of the first. Group A shows impaired recall of the first list after learning the second, which is the reverse of what proactive interference predicts.
option_explanations.B: State-dependent learning holds that memory is facilitated when internal states at encoding and retrieval match. The study controls for sleep and makes no mention of differing physiological or emotional states between learning and test; the design provides no basis for attributing the group difference to state changes.
option_explanations.C: Motivated forgetting involves the active, often unconscious suppression of emotionally threatening memories. The paired-associate lists are emotionally neutral laboratory stimuli, and the design offers no mechanism by which motivation to forget would selectively affect Group A's first-list recall.
option_explanations.D: Retroactive interference occurs when newly learned material disrupts retrieval of previously learned information. Group A's second-list learning (new, similar material) impaired recall of the first list (original material), while Group B's arithmetic interpolation produced no such impairment. The equivalence of sleep and initial learning performance rules out consolidation and encoding differences, leaving backward interference from the second list as the most precise explanation.

questions.vignette: Natalie learned an extensive set of client intake procedures during her first month as a clinic coordinator and performed them accurately for years. After her clinic adopted a completely redesigned intake system, she spent three weeks mastering the new workflow until she executed it seamlessly. During a staff audit conducted shortly after, Natalie was asked to walk evaluators through the original procedures, which she had not practiced since the transition. She hesitated frequently, reversed steps, and omitted items she had once known without effort, yet showed no such difficulty with any other long-standing work skills. Colleagues pointed out that Natalie's memory and concentration had been sharp throughout the transition period, and she had not experienced any illness, significant stress, or notable sleep disruption.
questions.question: Which memory phenomenon most precisely accounts for Natalie's difficulty with the original intake procedures?

options.A: Proactive interference
options.C: Encoding specificity
options.D: Decay theory

option_explanations.A: Proactive interference occurs when earlier-acquired information disrupts recall of later-acquired information. Natalie's original procedures would be the 'old' learning and the redesigned workflow the 'new' learning; proactive interference would predict difficulty with the new workflow, not the old one. Because the impairment involves the original (older) procedures, proactive interference predicts the wrong direction of forgetting.
option_explanations.B: Retroactive interference occurs when newly learned material impairs retrieval of previously learned material. Natalie's thorough learning of the new intake workflow (new material, high similarity to original) disrupted her ability to retrieve the original procedures she once knew automatically. The scenario rules out encoding weakness (years of accurate performance), passive decay (brief time gap), and neurological causes (no illness or cognitive change), leaving the backward interference of new on old learning as the only precise fit.
option_explanations.C: Encoding specificity predicts that recall suffers when the cues present at retrieval differ from those at encoding. Although the physical context may have changed slightly with the new system, Natalie is being tested in the same workplace where she originally learned the procedures, and no context mismatch is described. Encoding specificity cannot account for the selective failure on only the original procedures while new skills remain intact.
option_explanations.D: Decay theory attributes forgetting to the passive fading of memory traces over time through disuse. Natalie had not practiced the original procedures since the transition, which could suggest disuse, but the scenario emphasizes that the forgetting appeared shortly after intensive learning of similar new material rather than gradually over a long interval. Decay also cannot explain why other long-standing work skills are unaffected, nor why the impairment is selective to procedures with a directly competing learned alternative.

questions.vignette: A cognitive psychologist is teaching a seminar on Baddeley's model of working memory. She explains that one component is responsible for temporarily holding auditory information, such as spoken words or the sound of a melody, for a brief period. This component relies on an articulatory rehearsal process that refreshes the stored sounds before they decay. The researcher notes that damage to this system impairs a person's ability to repeat back a string of spoken digits immediately after hearing them. She describes this subsystem as the component most directly engaged when someone mentally 'hears' a phone number they were just told.
questions.question: Which component of Baddeley's working memory model is being described in this seminar?

options.A: The visuospatial sketchpad
options.C: The phonological loop
options.D: The episodic buffer

option_explanations.A: The visuospatial sketchpad is a working memory subsystem that temporarily holds and manipulates visual and spatial information, such as mental images or locations in space. The vignette specifically describes the storage of auditory and spoken information, which is the domain of the phonological loop, not the sketchpad.
option_explanations.B: The central executive is the supervisory component of Baddeley's model that coordinates attentional resources and directs the subsidiary slave systems. It does not itself store auditory information; rather, it manages and allocates processing between the other components.
option_explanations.C: The phonological loop is the subsystem in Baddeley's working memory model specifically dedicated to the temporary storage of auditory and verbal information. It consists of a phonological store that holds sound-based information and an articulatory rehearsal process that refreshes it, exactly as described in the vignette.
option_explanations.D: The episodic buffer is a later addition to Baddeley's model that serves as a temporary interface between working memory subsystems and long-term memory, integrating information across different modalities. It is not the primary system for storing auditory traces, which is the defining function of the phonological loop.

questions.vignette: A 34-year-old graduate student with a history of mild anxiety is participating in a memory research study. questions.question: The pattern of errors observed in this study is most directly attributable to a limitation of which memory system?

options.A: The episodic buffer
options.C: Sensory (echoic) memory
options.D: The visuospatial sketchpad

option_explanations.B: The phonological loop stores information in a sound-based (phonological) code. option_explanations.C: Echoic (sensory) memory holds raw auditory input for a very brief period (roughly 2–4 seconds) before it is processed further. option_explanations.D: The visuospatial sketchpad handles visual and spatial information, not sound-based representations. options.C: The visuospatial sketchpad
options.D: The phonological loop
