questions.vignette: A man in his mid-forties participates in a laboratory study several years after a surgical procedure intended to reduce severe and uncontrollable episodes of brain-based electrical disturbances. Images appear on a screen for less than a tenth of a second — too brief for the eyes to move — while the man's chin rests in a fixed support keeping his gaze centered. A picture of a key appears on the left side of the screen and a picture of a cup appears on the right side. Asked to say what he saw, the man answers 'cup' without hesitation. Immediately after, he is told to reach with his left hand into a bag containing several small objects and pull out the one that matches what he was shown; he withdraws a small metal key. When the examiner asks him to do the same with his right hand, he pulls out an object shaped like a cup. The man looks at the key in his left hand with a confused expression and says, 'That's not right — I said cup.'
questions.question: Which phenomenon most precisely accounts for the full pattern of this man's behavior, including his verbal response, his left-hand selection, his right-hand selection, and his verbal denial of the left-hand choice?

options.A: A failure of conscious visual attention causing the man to register only one image and randomly guess when required to provide a second response with his non-dominant hand
options.B: Functional separation between the two sides of the brain such that each side independently processed a different image and directed the response of the hand it controls, while verbal output reflects only what one side perceived
options.C: An involuntary reaching disorder caused by damage near the area governing intentional movement, producing accurate but unwanted object selection with the left hand that contradicts the man's spoken intention
options.D: A memory encoding failure specific to briefly presented stimuli on the left side, causing the man to correctly identify the right-side image verbally while his left hand defaults to a familiar or recently encountered object

option_explanations.A: A unilateral attentional failure would mean the man consistently fails to register one side of the display, resulting in chance-level or systematically absent responses for one visual field. However, both selections — left hand retrieving the key and right hand retrieving the cup — are specifically and accurately matched to the image shown in each corresponding visual hemifield. This consistent, stimulus-specific accuracy across both sides rules out a random or attentional account.
option_explanations.B: This is correct. The full pattern — verbal report of cup, left-hand retrieval of key, right-hand retrieval of cup, and verbal denial of the left hand's accurate choice — is precisely explained by interhemispheric disconnection. The side of the brain that controls speaking received the right-side image (cup) and reports it verbally. The opposite side received the left-side image (key) and accurately directed left-hand retrieval. Because information cannot cross between the two sides, the speaking side has no knowledge of what the other side perceived, causing genuine confusion about the left hand's accurate but unexplained behavior. No other option explains all four response elements simultaneously.
option_explanations.C: An involuntary reaching disorder would be characterized by movements that are not purposefully directed toward a specific target matching a prior stimulus, but instead appear goal-directed in a conflicting or random way. The man's left-hand selection is not random or conflicting — it accurately retrieves the specific object matching the image shown to the left side of the display. This purposeful, stimulus-specific accuracy is incompatible with an involuntary reaching disorder, which would not reliably produce correct object matching.
option_explanations.D: A memory encoding deficit specific to briefly presented left-side stimuli would result in the left hand failing to select the correct object or performing at chance — not accurately retrieving the specific stimulus shown. The man's left hand retrieves the key, which is the exact match for the left-side image, demonstrating that the information was encoded and retained well enough to guide a purposeful manual search. A memory failure cannot explain this accuracy.
